c 1500 bc First evidence for some languages of the Indo-European group. c 1000–500 bc Emergence of Proto-Germanic. c 300–200 bc Break-up of Proto-Germanic. c 45–c 410 Britain becomes part of the Roman Empire, forming the Roman colony ‘Britannia’
Bede completes his Ecclesiastical History of the English People
Printing of The Recuyell of the Historyes of Troye by William Caxton in Bruges—the first book to be printed in English
William Caxton sets up his printing press in Westminster and publishes the first printed books in England
Henry VII becomes the first Tudor King after Richard III is killed at the Battle of Bosworth
French no longer used as the language of Parliament

note: 1490 Caxton’s Eneydos published (with prologue remarking on variability of English).

title: Death of Caxton; succeeded by Wynkyn de Worde, who moves his printing press to
Christopher Columbus arrives in West Indies
John Cabot reaches Newfoundland, providing the first English contact with Canada

publisher: Publication of William Tyndale’s New Testament in English

title: English Reformation (Henry VIII breaks with the Catholic Church
Publication of Miles Coverdale’s Bible (the first complete Bible to be printed in English
First act of union between England and Wales
Fyrst Boke of the Introduction of Knowledge, illustrates regional dialects
John Hawkins starts British slave trade
Birth of Shakespeare
Vocabularium Saxiconum, first Old English glossary; included northern English words
A Caveat or Warening for Common Cursetors, first glossary of the ‘canting language’ or dialect of the underworld
Francis Drake circumnavigates the world
Thomas Herriot, a scientist, visits Roanoke in America to gather information on the flora, fauna, resources, people, and languages
Publication of William Bullokar’s Pamphlet for Grammar, the first grammar of English
Founding of the East India Company
English begins to be used in records of legal proceedings
Union of the Crowns; James VI of Scotland succeeds to the English throne, as James I, after death of Elizabeth I
A Table Alphabeticall, the first English–English dictionary, translates ‘hard words’ and inkhorn terms into ‘common
Jamestown in Chesapeake Bay founded in North America—the first successful British colony
The Authorized Version of the English Bible (the ‘King James’ Bible), attempts to resolve questions about Englishing the Word of God
Death of Shakespeare
Logonomia Anglica, first vernacular grammar to treat English dialects systematically
Publication of the First Folio edition of Sheakespeare’s plays
Publication of John Wallis’s Grammatica linguae Anglicanae
Britain ousts the Spanish from Jamaica and extends its influence and language into the Caribbean and to West Africa
1 Restoration of the monarchy. 2 Royal Society of London founded, in part, as the first English language academy
Hudson’s Bay Company formed. 1710 Copyright Act
Publication of Greenwood’s Essay towards a practical English Grammar

Publication (anonymously) of A Proposal for Correcting, Improving and Ascertaining the English Tongue; in a Letter by Jonathan Swift, which proposes the foundation of an Academy to regulate English usage
Having defeated the French, the British exile French-speakers from present-day Illinois failed, and their defeat at Battle of Quebec in 1759 ensures dominance by English speakers in the west
Death of Queen Anne: all chances of setting up an English Academy lost
Elisabeth Elstob published the first grammar of Old English
c 1745 Publication of Ann Fisher’s New Grammar (Newcastle upon Tyne), the first grammar to be published by a woman
Samuel Johnson published the Plan for his Dictionary
Britain (and its colonies) move from the Julian to the Gregorian calendar, losing 11 days between 2 and 14 September
Publication of Samuel Johnson’s two-volume Dictionary of the English Language

container-title: In the hands of expatriate and native soldiers and bureaucrats, English becomes the language of government
title: In India, the British military victory at Plassy institutes English dominance in South Asia that will last until 1947
Publication of Robert Lowth’s Short Introduction to English Grammar
Botany Bay, Australia, discovered by James Cook
War of American Independence begins
Publication of Thomas Sheridan’s General Dictionary of the English Language. One main object of which, is, to establish a plain and permanent standard of pronunciation
US Declaration of Independence formally recognized by the British
Noah Webster’s American Spelling Book (the ‘Blue-backed Speller’) published
Abolitionists in Britain establish Sierra Leone in West Africa and settle 2000 freed slaves there. They employ English in governing themselves and the indigenous peoples
Establishment of a penal colony near present-day Sydney begins to form the distinctive English of Australia
Publication of Noah Webster’s Dissertations on the English Language, which advocated the institution of a national American standard of usage
Publication of John Walker’s Critical Pronouncing Dictionary and Expositor of the English Language
A delegation from Britain arrives in China to open trade relations. ‘Pidgin English’ begins to emerge as a trade language
Publication of Lindley Murray’s English Grammar, adapted to the different classes of learners. Over 1.5 million copies would be sold by 1850
Act of Union with Ireland
Union with Ireland begins
Purchasing the huge central portion of what is now the USA, the US government ensured the extension of English throughout much of the American west
1806 British establish control of South Africa (English becomes the official language in 1822
William Hazlitt publishes A New and Improved Grammar of the English Tongue
Liberia is supported by the USA as a place of re-settlement for freed slaves. All who arrive in Monrovia as part of this ‘colonization’ effort are English speakers
Opening of the Stockton to Darlington Railway
Publication of Noah Webster’s American Dictionary of the English Language
Opening of the Liverpool to Manchester Railway
1832 Passing of the First Reform Bill
Death of William IV; accession of Queen Victoria

container-title: 2 The Treaty of Waitangi was the foundation document in the establishment of exclusive British sovereignty in New Zealand
title: 1 In England, introduction of the Penny Post on 10 January; by the end of the year 168 million letters have been posted (compared to 76 million in 1839
1842 Foundation of the London Philological Society

note: 422 chronology
title: First telegraph line established between Baltimore and Washington

The annexation of Texas and the defeat of the Mexican army extends the USA westward to California. Vast numbers of migrants to the west, especially after the gold rush of 1848, overwhelm the institutions of Spanish culture
Public Libraries Act
Proposal for A New English Dictionary (later known as The Oxford English Dictionary) made by the London Philological Society
Atlantic Cable completed, linking Valencia, Ireland and Trinity Bay, Newfoundland by submarine cable

note: 2 Canada given self-government.
title: 1 Second Reform Bill (extending franchise to all those who could demonstrate ownership of property worth £7
Alexander Ellis publishes the first volume of his On Early English Pronunciation in which he defined ‘received pronunciation’ for the first time
1870 In England and Wales, Elementary Education Act passed, providing compulsory elementary education for all children
Education in Scotland made compulsory until the age of 14
Founding of the English Dialect Society

Invention of the phonograph by Thomas Edison
Education in England and Wales becomes compulsory until the age of 10
First fascicle of A New English Dictionary on Historical Principles (later OED) published, covering the words A-Ant
The British East Africa Company is established to oversee the development of British interests in Kenya

exclude most Indians from South Africa. 3 Death of Queen Victoria

title: The Englishman Sir Evelyn Wrench and the American Alexander Smith Cochran found the English-Speaking Union, to encourage partnership between the UK, its dominions, and the USA
The German colony of Tanganyika in East Africa is ceded to Britain, and Kamerun in West Central Africa is divided between France (Cameroun) and Britain

container-title: Gaelic is made an ‘official’ language in addition to English
title: Ireland achieves Home Rule and is separated from Great Britain

The Afrikaans language gains official status alongside English in South Africa
Completion of the first edition of the Oxford English Dictionary
The British Commonwealth is formed, and South Africa becomes a dominion of the British Empire
The British Council is founded, with its headquarters in London, as a vehicle for British cultural diplomacy and teaching English as a foreign or second language
The Philippines becomes a self-governing Commonwealth in association with the USA
The Republic of Ireland severs all constitutional links with Great Britain

note: 1939–45 The Second World War (UK), World War II (US).
title: In Wales, a new constitution for the festival the National Eisteddfod makes Welsh its official language
Signing of the United Nations Charter and the decision to make the headquarters of the UN in the USA gives English an unprecedented importance as a language of diplomacy
1 The Philippines gains its independence from the USA
Burma gains its independence from the UK, and declines membership of the Commonwealth. 3 Ceylon gains its independence from the UK as Sri Lanka, and joins the Commonwealth
